key_points: Schools across the U.S. are grappling with responding to vague threats made on social media.
The increase in threats has been noted after the tragedy at Oxford High, which left four dead.
In one week following the Oxford incident, over 150 threats were reported nationwide.
School administrators face the dilemma of closing schools or keeping them open amid these threats.
Some schools opt for virtual learning, while others implement lockdown protocols.
Experts emphasize taking every threat seriously but raise concerns about the repercussions of frequent school closures.
Fake threats and accounts complicate the identification of genuine dangers.
Some threats are linked to students' mental health issues exacerbated by the pandemic.
In some cases, detailed investigations into threats lead to arrests and charges.
Legislation is being proposed to increase funding for school support personnel.
spokespersons: James Densley (Professor of Criminal Justice, Metropolitan State University)
Jason Enix (Superintendent, Reading Community City School District)
Daniel McGarry (Superintendent, Upper Darby School District)
